Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop new computational methods to study the gravitational waves generated during the inspiral and merger of co-orbiting black holes. The approach uses techniques for solving Einstein's equations which have been recently developed in collaboration with computational mathematicians and thoroughly calibrated on test problems. They have been implemented as a community resource in the Einstein toolkit, which is used by the many research groups involved in black hole simulations. The techniques will be further developed to measure the loss of energy and angular momentum carried off by the gravitational waves.

Waves, such as water, sound and electromagnetic waves, are a prominent feature of physical systems. A revolutionary prediction of Einstein's gravitational theory is that accelerated bodies produce gravitational waves, analogous to the way electric charges produce electromagnetic waves. At present, gravitational waves have only been detected indirectly by the way they deplete energy from two co-orbiting pulsars. A Laser Interferometric Gravity Wave Observatory (LIGO) has been constructed that is expected to open up a new form of astronomy by direct detection of these waves. The most powerful source of gravitational waves is the inspiral and merger of two co-orbiting black holes. Computer simulations provide the theoretical details necessary for LIGO to tune in on the gravitational signal and monitor the dynamics of the merger.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A revolutionary prediction of Einstein's general theory of relativity is that accelerated bodies produce gravitational waves, Recently, gravitational waves emanating from the inspiral and merger of two co-orbiting black holes have been detected by the Laser Interferometric Gravity Wave Observatory (LIGO). This discovery is expected to open up a new form of astronomy. Although Einstein's equations describe the production of gravitational waves, their complexity makes a purely analytic approach inadequate. This has necessitated the introduction of numerical methods into general relativity. Computer simulations provide the theoretical details necessary for LIGO to tune in the gravitational signal and monitor the dynamics of the merger. This project has developed advanced computational methods to simulate the production of gravitational waves from black holes.


The project has combined two topics central to modern technology
and science: the production of waves and the development of
computational methods. The specific research has been imotivated by gravitational theory but water, sound, elastic and electromagnetic waves obey similar systems of wave equations and require similar computational treatment. In tackling  the complexity of Einstein's equations,  the project has involved international experts spanning applied mathematics, computation, gravitational theory and astrophysics. It has led to new methods which have found application not only by numerical relativists but also by others working on this broad class of systems. These methods have been implemented as part of the Einstein toolkit, which is a resource available publicly to the numerical relativity community. Besides lecturing, advising, preparing review articles, participation in workshops and serving on thesis committees, the research projects and resulting publications have involved and contributed to the training of numerous graduate students and postdocs, encompassing both genders and a multitude of nationalities.
